skill.name: clojure-review
skill.description: Review Clojure and ClojureScript code changes for compliance with Metabase coding standards, style violations, and code quality issues. Use when reviewing pull requests or diffs containing Clojure/ClojureScript code.

skill.author: metabase

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only a markdown documentation file with code review guidelines. It has no executable code, no network capabilities, no filesystem operations beyond reading for review, and no environment variable access. The skill is purely instructional, providing style guide rules and review checklists for Clojure code.

content.user_title: Review Clojure code against Metabase style standards
content.value_statement: Clojure code reviews require deep knowledge of style guides and project conventions. This skill automates style checking and flags violations in pull requests.
actual_capabilities: Checks naming conventions for functions and variables
Validates docstring presence and format on public vars
Verifies test naming and parallel test annotations
Reviews REST API endpoint conventions and schemas
Flags TODO comments missing author and date
Identifies functions that should be marked private
limitations: Requires reading the code diff or file content first
Does not catch parentheses issues (defers to linter)
Style rules are specific to Metabase conventions
Cannot run automated tests or linters directly

use_cases.title: Review pull request changes
use_cases.description: Check Clojure code changes in a PR for style guide compliance before requesting review from maintainers.

use_cases.title: Enforce consistent code style
use_cases.description: Use during code reviews to ensure all team members follow the same naming and documentation conventions.

use_cases.title: Learn Clojure best practices
use_cases.description: Reference the checklist to understand what reviewers look for and avoid common style mistakes.

prompt_templates.title: Quick style check
prompt_templates.scenario: Fast review of a single file
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this Clojure file for style violations: [paste code]

prompt_templates.title: PR diff review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review the Clojure changes in this PR diff for Metabase style guide compliance. Flag only violations, no positive feedback.

prompt_templates.title: Naming convention check
prompt_templates.prompt: Check these function names for Clojure conventions. Pure functions should be nouns. Side-effect functions need ! suffix.

prompt_templates.title: API endpoint review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this API endpoint code for Metabase REST conventions. Check route naming, parameter case, and response schemas.

output: Naming issue: Pure function should be named as a noun
Missing docstring: Add documentation explaining the return value

best_practices: Run the skill on diffs rather than entire files to focus feedback
Combine with automated linters for complete coverage
Use the quick checklist for self-review before requesting feedback
anti_patterns: Do not expect praise for correct code - the skill only flags issues
Do not use for parentheses errors - those are caught by the linter
Do not apply Metabase-specific rules to non-Metabase projects

faq.question: Which AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Claude Code, and Codex. It provides review guidelines that any AI assistant can follow.

faq.question: What are the limits of this skill?
faq.answer: The skill provides style feedback only. It cannot run tests, execute linters, or make automated fixes to your code.

faq.question: How do I integrate this with my workflow?
faq.answer: Paste your code diff or file content when prompting. The skill will return a list of style violations to address.

faq.question: Is my code sent to external servers?
faq.answer: This skill is purely instructional with no network capabilities. Code is only processed by the AI assistant you are using.

faq.question: Why is the skill not catching syntax errors?
faq.answer: Syntax and parentheses errors are excluded by design. Use clj-kondo or another linter for those checks.

faq.question: How does this compare to clj-kondo?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on style and conventions. clj-kondo handles syntax and static analysis. Use both for complete coverage.
